comments: Permanent of the (0,1)-matrix having (i,j)-th entry equal to 0 iff this is on the diagonal or the first upper-diagonal. - _Simone Severini_, Oct 14 2004From _Vladimir Shevelev_, Jun 21 2015: (Start)Let 2*n!*V(n) be the number of ways of seating n married couples at 2*n chairs arranged side-by-side in a straight line, men and women in alternate positions, so that no husband is next to his wife.It is known [Riordan, Ch. 8, Th. 1, t=0] that, if 2*n!*U(n) is a solution of an analogous problem at a circular table, then U(n) = V(n) - V(n-1), n>=3, where U(n) = A000179(n). Thus V(n) = Sum_{i=3,...,n} A000179(i), n>=1, and comparing the initial conditions, we conclude that a(n) = V(n), n>=1. This gives a combinatorial interpretation for 2*n!*a(n).(End)
